;;L;;ast; ;年份 ;中国国家主席习近平考察;黑龙江< /a>; 位于该国东北部。作为中国工业锈带的一部分，该省是困扰中国经济问题的典型例子。其;出生率< /a>; 是全国最低的。最大城市的;房价;正在下降。 2023年，该省的<小>;GDP;仅增长2.6％。更糟糕的是，在扣除通货膨胀因素之前，其名义<小>;GDP;几乎没有增长，这表明该省正处于深度<小>;GDP的增长之中。 a href="https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/08/10/deflation-and-default-haunt-chinas-economy">;通货紧缩;。

;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-121tnhw e1tt35bk0">;永远不要害怕：习近平有一个计划。在访问期间，他敦促省里的听众培育“新生产力”。此后，这句话在官方报纸和官方集会上多次出现。 ;上个月的会议强调了这一点“两会”;，中国橡皮图章议会及其咨询机构的年度会议。北京大学的王先清在一本关于这一主题的新书的序言中将这个词比作“改革开放”，这个公式概括了中国在 1978 年之后拥抱市场力量的情况。他写道，这些词即使在今天仍然“闪耀”，暗示“新生产力”将具有类似的持久力。

;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;

;闪亮的文字是什么意思？中国官员正在寻找为国家经济提供动力的方法。多年来，其生产力依赖于劳动力的动员和资本的积累。从 1996 年到 2015 年，中国的劳动力增加了 1 亿。据智库亚洲生产力组织称，其资本存量从 2001 年占 GDP 的 258% 上升到二十年后的 349%。 2007-09 年全球金融危机之后，大部分资本积累采取了新的房地产和基础设施的形式。

;

;中国的劳动力现在经济萎缩，房地产需求;大幅下滑< /a>;：越来越少的人搬到中国城市，房地产投机收益不再有保障，潜在购房者不愿提前购买公寓，以免陷入困境的开发商在建筑完工前耗尽现金。房地产低迷损害了消费者信心，并剥夺了地方政府从土地销售中获得的重要收入。即使在中国放弃严格的 covid-19 控制之后，经济复苏仍持续;静音且不均匀;。支出还不足以充分利用中国现有的生产力。因此，根据一项衡量标准，通货紧缩已经连续持续了四个季度。

;;
;;
;

;在中国的发展阶段，经济通常以服务业为中心。但政府的心却在别处。这场大流行增加了对中国制成品的需求，从外科口罩到健身自行车。美国对“瓶颈技术”的出口管制也产生了对本土替代品的需求，从光刻机到航空级不锈钢。中国的第十四个五年计划（2021-25 年）承诺维持制造业占 GDP 的比重，该比重已从 2006 年的近三分之一下降到 2020 年的四分之一多一点（见图表）。 /p>;

;在寻求先进且自给自足的制造体系的过程中，中国长期以来采取了各种有益的政策。例如，其教育部最近批准了一个新的本科专业;高端半导体科学与工程;。根据智库战略与国际研究中心的数据，2019 年中国用于更明确的产业政策（包括补贴、税收减免和廉价信贷）的支出占 GDP 的 1.7%，超过是美国支出百分比的三倍。

;
;
;
;
;;
;

;“中国真正想成为下一次工业革命的领导者，”咨询公司龙洲经讯 (Gavekal Dragonomics) 的 Tilly 张表示。这将要求它升级传统产业，打破外国对现有技术的束缚，并为未来产业开辟新道路。尽管中央政府的野心令人印象深刻，甚至令人不安，但如果没有资金短缺的地方政府和信心不足的私营企业家的帮助，它就不可能成功。因此，新口号可能暴露出一种破坏性的远视——远见，导致领导层忽视更紧迫的经济问题。

;;

;猫头鹰展开翅膀

;

;对于加州大学圣地亚哥分校的巴里·诺顿（Barry Naughton）来说，他承认年轻时读过一些黑格尔，“新生产力”一词唤起了“辩证”思想，即积累正如黑格尔所说，量的变化可能会导致质的突破或突然的飞跃，就像温度的逐渐升高将水变成蒸汽一样。与此同时，马克思指出，当新的生产力在经济中取得足够的分量时，它们就可以重塑社会秩序：“手磨坊给你带来了封建领主的社会，”他写道，“蒸汽磨坊给了你一个工业资本主义的社会。 ”。那么，新生产力可以是一件大事。

;

;但在提出这一概念时，习近平表示，新生产力的检验推动力将是“全要素生产率”的提高，这个术语不是出自马克思，而是出自主流经济学。它是指不能归因于可衡量投入（例如资本、劳动力和人力资本）增加的产出增加。诺顿先生表示，通过混合马克思主义和新古典主义概念，新生产力是一头“奇怪的混合野兽”。

;

;根据习近平的说法，新的生产力将从科学技术应用到生产中涌现。这句话是一个信号，表明中国的技术推动应该比现在更加雄心勃勃，并更紧密地融入经济生产。中国领导人承诺“举全国之力”推动技术自力更生。 3月份公布的中央政府预算将科技支出增加了10%，达到3710亿元人民币（500亿美元），是所有部门中增幅最大的。节俭创新，这不是。

;

;这也不是中国首次尝试解决这个问题。 2006 年，一项 15 年计划设定了国家目标，以增加研发 (;R;&;D;) 支出、减少对外国技术的依赖并提高技术对增长的贡献。它还确定了16个“大型项目”，例如建造中国自己的大型客机和在月球上着陆探测器。这些主要是复制现有技术的尝试。 2010年，全球金融危机爆发后，中国改变策略，大力刺激各种“战略性新兴产业”，包括新型信息技术、可再生能源和;电动汽车; (;EV; s）——其中许多仍处于萌芽阶段。

;

;六年后，中国再次转移了重点。其“创新驱动发展战略”表达了对世界正处于另一场工业革命之中的信念。数字技术、物联网、绿色技术和 ;人工智能; (;AI;)有望在经济的各个领域取得突破。中国的新战略并没有选择各种新兴产业，而是强调了相互增强的技术集群。中国的目标是到本世纪中叶成为创新的“世界强国”。据咨询公司荣鼎集团称，到 2020 年，中国在科技方面的支出已接近 2.9 亿元人民币（占 GDP 的 2.8%）。如果算上慷慨的税收减免的话，政府的贡献超过了60%。在获奖者中，六分之一最终进入了大学或研究机构。大约 60% 流向了公司。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;诺顿先生称中国的创新战略是“历史上政府资源对产业政策目标最伟大的单一承诺”。国家必须为此展示什么？迄今为止，结果好于任何中等收入国家的预期。但它们并不像中国领导人希望的那样令人印象深刻。

;

;在;电子商务、金融科技、高铁和可再生能源，中国正处于或接近技术领先地位边境。同样的情况在<小>;电动汽车;领域表现得尤为明显，它的成功帮助中国去年成为全球最大的汽车出口国。在智库澳大利亚政策研究所确定的 64 项“关键”技术清单中，根据该领域最有影响力的论文数量，中国在除 11 项之外的所有技术上均领先世界。该国在5<小>;G;和6<小>;G;通信以及生物制造、纳米制造和增材制造方面排名第一。它在无人机、雷达、机器人和声纳以及后量子密码学方面也处于领先地位。

;

;白热化

;

;中国在国家创新“生态系统”的更广泛衡量方面也取得了良好进展。全球创新指数由世界知识产权组织发布，综合了约 80 个指标，涵盖基础设施、法规和市场条件，以及研究工作、专利奖项和引用次数。中国的人均GDP预计排在60多位，属于中等收入国家。中国排名第 12 位。

;

;这些成就的经济影响更难以衡量。中国的“战略性新兴产业”清单自2010年推出以来一直在不断变化，因此很难追踪进展情况。中国国家统计局的两名官员曾感叹，纳入标准，特别是产品层面的标准“模糊”。如何知道锅炉算“节能”还是复合材料算“高性能”？尽管如此，中国统计人员预计，2021年战略性新兴产业占GDP的比重将达到13.4%，高于2014年的7.6%，但低于2020年15%的原定目标。相比之下，房地产建设和服务业的增加值（忽略钢铁、铁矿石和其他此类行业的上游环节）约为 12%。

;

;尽管这些成果令人印象深刻，但中国领导人并不满足。他们对美国的技术禁运和最近的技术胜利感到震惊。对芯片和芯片制造设备销售的全面出口管制暴露了​​中国对外国零部件、软件和设备的依赖。美国在;AI;方面的进步也引发了反思。 ;人工智能;是中国认为自己具有优势的行业。该国领导人对 2022 年推出的 Chat;GPT;（Open;AI; 开发的大型语言模型）感到震惊。

;

;中国的进步也受到了自己领导人的伤害。 2021 年，他们严厉打击了中国许多领先的科技公司，指责它们处理数据不当、阻碍竞争和剥削零工工人。这场监管风暴针对的是阿里巴巴和美团等面向消费者的“平台”公司，而不是先进制造商或其他“硬科技”公司。然而，对投资者信心的损害却难以遏制。那些不受欢迎的平台公司拥有大量数据，也是许多前沿技术的主要投资者，例如中国领导人热衷于培育的人工智能。据荣鼎咨询称，2023 年上半年，中国大型互联网公司的研发支出较上年同期削减了近 7%。

;

;全要素生产率增长（习近平先生首选的新生产力测试）也已放缓。中国2006年推出的科技计划意味着其对经济增长的贡献率将上升至60%。相反，根据信用评级机构;S;&;P;全球评级公司Louis Kuijs的计算，这一数字已降至不到三分之一。因此，中国正遭受着自己版本的“索洛悖论”：除了生产率统计数据之外，你到处都可以看到一个新的技术时代。这些挫折和缺点可能解释了为什么需要一个新的口号来改变现状。

;

;国家的创新推动现在似乎分为三个部分。它决心复制世界其他国家可能会试图否认的“窒息”技术。第二个目标是发明世界其他地区尚未创造的技术。今年1月，科技部会同其他六部委发布了一份“未来产业”清单，其中许多产业比过去的战略性新兴产业更具开创性。它们包括光子计算、脑机接口、核聚变和数字双胞胎——医生可以监测患者的数字拟像，以监测现实生活中可能出现的疾病。中国政府鼓励实验室和研究机构将一半以上的基础研究资金花在 35 岁以下的科学家身上，相信他们更有可能取得国家所需的突破。

;

;这些登月计划可能被视为中国无法承受的愚蠢之举——分散了人们对自力更生的顽强追求，而自力更生需要中国不再依赖的本土技术版本从国外进口。但Gavekal的张女士表示，中国领导人希望未来产业能够在未来的科技战中为国家提供“讨价还价的筹码”，从而间接为国家的技术主权做出贡献。如果美国威胁切断中国获得重要物资的渠道，中国可以进行同样的报复。

;

;拐弯抹角

;

;中国评论员经常谈论“弯道超车”。长期以来，中国未能取代现有的传统汽车制造商，但在电动汽车领域取得的成功表明，有时在尚未被根深蒂固的现有企业占据的领域取得进展会更容易。北京对外经济贸易大学的毛杰及其合著者表示，2000年至2012年中国的科技政策对发酵行业生产率的提升最为显着，而不是国内已经成熟的行业或国外。在打游击战争时，毛泽东主张先占领农村再进城。同样，中国可能正在进军技术发现领域，而其根深蒂固的对手在这些领域的优势较小。

;
;
;< div id="econ-4" class="adComponent_adcontainer__eooQr">;
;
;
;

;第三个目标是升级现有产业。北京大学的王勇认为，“即使是最传统的农业，只要采用革命性的技术，也能形成新的生产力”。他引用了使用大数据的自动化种植或选择性育种。在两届全国人大及其咨询机构的年会上，一位来自著名国有酒厂的代表甚至指出，新的生产力可以在艰苦的精神中找到。

;

;追求这些目标将付出高昂的代价。过去十到十五年的一个教训是，大量的货币并不能保证黑格尔式的生产转型。但缺乏支出肯定会排除这一可能性。

;

;因此，中国领导人一定会担心地方政府预算捉襟见肘和动物精神低落。过去，中国科技发展的大部分资金来自地方政府资金，这些资金通过土地出售和“特别债券”筹集资金。从 2020 年到 2023 年，他们的收入下降了五分之一以上。

;

;当经济蓬勃发展、地方当局现金充裕时，他们智库卡内基国际和平基金会的马特·希恩 (Matt Sheehan) 指出，美国可以自由地投资那些可能在五年或十年内无法获得回报的企业。例如，2010 年，经济增长正在反弹，刺激资金可能会涌入电动汽车、太阳能电池板和其他不断发展的技术。但他预测，对于当今更加困难时期的地方政府来说，“经济救火最终将压垮长期思考的尝试”。将敦促公司投资提供短期回报的项目。他们还可能因税收和费用而受到困扰和骚扰，以帮助其省或市的赞助人平衡其收支。

;

;在今年的两届会议上，中国总理李强阐述了国家未来一年的“主要任务”。李克强的首要任务是“实现产业体系现代化”和发展“优质新生产力”。扩大内需是消除通货紧缩的必要手段，但仅排名第三。如果情绪和市场没有复苏，地方政府将难以补充国库，私人投资可能会出现短缺。习近平决心重塑中国经济。为此，他需要先重新充气。 ;■;

;;我;;T WAS应该是一场庆祝活动。 3 月 28 日，美国职业棒球大联盟 (;MLB;) 2024 赛季开幕日，;大谷翔平;首次代表洛杉矶道奇队在道奇体育场上场。在他第一次击球时，球迷们都站起来，伸长脖子，相机咔哒作响，渴望一睹“Shotime”的表演。他的才华是惊人的。在去年的一场比赛中，大谷先生三振了十名击球手并打出两支本垒打，这是只有少数球员才能完成的壮举。但最近乌云遮住了他的明星。

;

;3 月 20 日，《洛杉矶时报》; 和 ;体育频道 ESPN 爆料称，联邦调查人员正在调查从大谷先生的银行账户电汇至加州一家涉嫌非法博彩公司的 450 万美元。这位日本棒球明星指责他的朋友兼长期翻译水原一平偷钱来偿还赌债，并坚称他正在与官员充分合作。水原先生向 ESPN 表示，大谷先生同意帮助偿还他的债务。不管大谷先生本人是否做错了什么（目前尚不清楚数百万美元如何在他或他的银行没有注意到的情况下从他的账户中消失），丑闻将一直困扰着他，直到调查结束。尽管令人沮丧，但这些爆料也提醒人们，;MLB; 对大谷先生的巨星地位有多么依赖。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;从他的棒球技巧。这项运动缓慢的节奏和对变革的抵制未能吸引年轻人。由于最近对;加快速度;。但美国职业棒球大联盟（MLB）迫切需要像大谷先生这样的运动员，他在2017年与洛杉矶天使队签约之前曾在日本打球，洛杉矶天使队是一支位于阿纳海姆的道奇队的球队。大谷先生是一位罕见的双向球员，这意味着他在投手丘上和在击球区一样具有杀伤力。没有哪位球员在这两方面都像他一样出色，这让许多人猜测他可能是这项运动有史以来最好的球员。即使他不是最伟大的（有些人会认为另一位双向球员贝比·鲁斯），他也是迄今为止这项运动有史以来最伟大的明星。考虑一下;MLB;球员的代言交易。 Ohtani 先生今年将赚到 6500 万美元。费城费城人队的布莱斯·哈珀（Bryce Harper）以 700 万美元排名第二。

;

;然后是他的国际吸引力。长期以来，美国以外的名人​​一直涌现：波多黎各的罗伯托·克莱门特、多米尼加共和国的阿尔伯特·普霍尔斯和日本的铃木一郎等等。开幕日之前，道奇队在首尔打了几场比赛。 ;MLB; 有充分的理由培养这种全球联系。随着美国对棒球的兴趣逐渐减弱，吸引更多外国球迷成为联盟高管的首要任务之一。

;;T;<小>;吉拉毒蜥;是一种有毒的北美蜥蜴，体长约 50 厘米，全身覆盖着独特的黑色和橙色鳞片。这种昏昏欲睡的爬行动物大多生活在地下，一年只吃三到四次，但却是制药业最大的重磅炸弹之一的灵感来源：;新一代减肥药;，拥有患者和;投资者;——疯狂。最初是为糖尿病而设计的，越来越多的证据表明它们对心脏、肾脏、肝脏等疾病也有好处。

;

;自晚期以来20世纪80年代的科学家认为，餐后肠道分泌的一种名为胰高血糖素样肽-1（<小>;GLP;-1）的肠道激素可以帮助治疗糖尿病。 ;GLP;-1 增加胰岛素（一种降低血糖水平的激素）的产生，并减少胰高血糖素（提高血糖水平）的产生。但;GLP;-1很快就会被体内的酶分解，因此它只停留几分钟。因此，如果将其用作药物，患者将面临每小时需要注射 ;GLP;-1 次的不良前景。

;1990 年，布朗克斯退伍军人事务医疗中心的研究员 John Eng 发现毒蜥毒液中发现的一种激素 exendin-4 与人类 ;GLP;-1 相似。至关重要的是，这种怪物在吃一顿稀有食物后释放的 exendin-4 比 ;GLP;-1 更能抵抗酶分解，可以在其体内停留数小时。十多年后，由美国制药巨头礼来公司和生物技术公司 Amylin Pharmaceuticals 开发的蜥蜴激素的合成版本艾塞那肽才在美国被批准用于治疗糖尿病。这一突破促使其他公司开发出更有效、更持久的 ;GLP;-1 药物，作为注射胰岛素之外的糖尿病治疗选择。

;

;科学家们还意识到;GLP;-1还有另一个副作用：它减慢了“胃排空”的速度，从而使食物在胃中停留的时间更长并抑制食欲。但最初并没有认真追求潜在的减肥益处。直到 2021 年，丹麦公司诺和诺德公司才展示了一项临床试验的数据，其中超重或肥胖患者每周服用一次基于 GLP-1 的糖尿病药物索马鲁肽，随后以 Ozempic 名称上市 68 周。结果非常引人注目，参与者的体重平均减轻了 15%。

; ;A psephological puzzle;

;Mr Modi's success among the well-educated does not come at the expense of support among other groups.事实上，像其他民粹主义领导人一样，他最大的进展是在下层选民中取得的，德里智库政策研究中心的政治学家尼兰詹·瑟卡(Neelanjan Sircar)说。 In 2020 Sanjay Kumar of the Centre for the Study of Developing Societies found that between 2014 and 2019 support for the ;BJP; increased among rural, lower-caste, young and poor voters.它在占人口近一半的“其他落后阶层”中增长得尤其快。 Among them, the ;BJP;'s support rose from 34% to 44%, compared with an increase of 31% to 37.5% among all voters.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This pattern of support for the ;BJP; is comparable to other countries in which less-educated or rural people have shifted right. But unlike many of his counterparts abroad, Mr Modi has also been able to increase his support among the educated. Three factors—class politics, economics, and elite admiration for strongman rule—help explain why.

;

;Start with class.在印度，这与种姓制度密切相关。 The ;BJP;, like many conservative parties, is known to be business-friendly.核心选区包括“巴尼亚”贸易社区的大部分成员，这是一个传统上以商业为导向的群体，集中在古吉拉特邦和拉贾斯坦邦等西北部各邦。 Tycoons such as Mukesh Ambani and Gautam Adani, India's richest men, fall into this group.包括刹帝利和婆罗门在内的上层种姓印度教徒也是核心支持基础的一部分。 Some regional parties, such as the ;DMK; in Tamil Nadu, have positioned themselves against such upper-caste groups. Congress, the main national opposition party, has championed preferential access to education and government jobs for lower castes.

;

;Mr Modi, himself from a relatively low caste, has marketed the ;BJP; as a caste-agnostic “pan-Hindu” party, allowing him to retain support from high-caste groups while extending the party's reach to others.瑟卡先生指出，印度各地受过良好教育的专业阶层普遍不认同德里的官僚、研究人员和媒体类型。 So Mr Modi's antipathy to the capital's elite has not cost him support among others elsewhere.

;

;The second factor is economic. Annual ;GDP; growth was 8.4% in the last quarter of 2023 (though because of quirks in how India measures its ;GDP;, the underlying figure is closer to 6.5%).尽管分布不均，但这种增长正在推动印度中上层阶级的规模和财富迅速增加。高盛将这种现象称为“富裕印度”的崛起。据统计，年收入1万美元或以上的印度人数量从2011年的2000万增加到2023年的6000万，到2027年将达到1亿。其中一个粗略指标是汽车销量。 Sales of cars, which tend to be bought by richer Indians, have grown by around 15% since before the pandemic. Sales of two-wheelers, which poorer folk buy, have fallen by just as much.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It is not surprising that Mr Modi has retained the support of those who have become richer.在2000年代末快速发展的时期，国大党在中上层阶级中得到了强有力的支持。 It took a slowdown and a series of corruption scandals in the 2010s to change things.

;

;But Mr Modi's tenure has increased India's economic and geopolitical standing in the world, too. One fund manager in Mumbai says that her friends worried about perceptions of India when Mr Modi was elected prime minister. He was chief minister of Gujarat during a bloody riot against Muslims there in 2002, an incident that saw him denied a visa to America for nine years. She thought Mr Modi might become a global pariah.事实上，情况恰恰相反。 Partly because of India's economic heft, and its importance as a counterweight to China, Mr Modi has been welcomed with open arms by leaders worldwide.

;

;Bigger, better...strongman ?

;

;Many university-educated Indians say they dislike Mr Modi's weaponisation of law enforcement against opposition parties and his government's treatment of Muslims as second-class公民。 The arrest on March 21st of ;Arvind Kejriwal;, the chief minister of Delhi, amplified these concerns. Still, as a banker in Mumbai notes, there is a widespread sense that the good parts of Mr Modi outweigh the bad. Indeed, some think a dose of strongman rule is exactly what India needs.

;

;This is the third reason for the prime minister's popularity among elites. They point to China and the East Asian tigers, the experiences of which they believe show that muscular governance can tear down barriers to economic growth. One industrialist in south India says that the country is “probably too democratic” given its level of income. Mr Modi, he adds, can “get shit done”.

;

;India's elites see Mr Modi's foreign policy as nationalist yet pragmatic. They like how he thumbs his nose at liberal Western institutions and the media, in a similar fashion to other anti-globalist strongmen, while promoting Indian interests. Mr Modi has negotiated four new trade deals since 2021, most recently with a grouping of four non-;EU; European countries on March 10th. In February, at the Raisina Dialogue in Delhi—India's version of the Munich Security Conference—his ministers lamented the ;UN;'s antiquated structure, while also positioning India as the leader of the global south.

;

;Admiration for leaders perceived as decisive is not new among India's elite. In the 1970s JRD Tata, one of India's most prominent industrialists, is said to have appreciated Indira Gandhi's imposition of “the Emergency”, a two-year-long suspension of normal democratic processes in response to a perceived threat to her power. A survey by Pew published in February found that 67% of Indians thought that “a system in which a strong leader can make decisions without interference from parliament or courts would be a good way of governing their country”. That figure, up from 55% in 2017, was the highest among the 24 countries surveyed. Many internationally minded Indians say Mr Trump is too autocratic for America but that Mr Modi is the right man for their country.

;

;So what could shake Mr Modi's elite fan base? Continued weaponisation of the state, as in the case of Mr Kejriwal, could come back to bite him; most elites still say they believe in democracy. And many of the people who say they like the prime minister also fear him, including those in business who know their survival depends on remaining in his good graces. That carries risks: according to Henley and Partners, a consultancy, India had a net outflow of 14,000 millionaires in 2022 and 2023, more than any country among those measured bar China, including Russia. By contrast Australia, Singapore and the ;UAE;, and five other countries, attracted over 1,000 millionaires in net inflows—reflecting, perhaps, their more predictable rule of law.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But for those who stay, even intensified autocracy may not be enough to weaken Mr Modi's appeal. In 2019 India's economy, reeling from a mini-financial crisis, slowed to a growth rate of 4%. While this weakness was not entirely Mr Modi's fault, his impulsive decision to swiftly demonetise large banknotes in 2016 had not helped. Elites complained, but apparently felt that Mr Modi was better for their wallets than the opposition, and voted for him.

;

;This is why many say that support for Mr Modi will continue until a credible alternative appears. Most elites have lost faith in Congress and its leader, Rahul Gandhi, who is seen as dynastic and out of touch. One senior Congress official even admits that Mr Modi “has taken our best ideas”, such as distributing welfare payments digitally, and “executed them better” than his party could have done. A stronger opposition is probably the only thing that will cause India's elites to abandon Mr Modi. But for now, that is nowhere in sight. ;■;

;;A ;;merica's 45th; president has excellent taste in ;Bible translations;. When deciding which one to endorse this Easter, Donald Trump chose the King James version, widely considered to be one of the greatest works of English literature of the 17th century. Or rather, he chose a modern repackaging of it dubbed the “God Bless the ;USA; Bible”. This includes in one volume the American constitution, the lyrics of a country song called “God Bless the ;USA;” and the scriptures.

;

;“All Americans need the Bible in their home, and I have many. It's my favourite book,“ intoned Mr Trump in a promotional video. “Religion is so important,” he added. “We must make America pray again.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And, tacitly, pay again: the new book costs $59.99 (plus postage). Mr Trump is not selling it directly, but receives royalties with each purchase, according to the ;New York Times;. Thus, he has entered the highly competitive business of trying to make a buck from the holy book.

;

;This is a new kind of venture for Mr Trump, whose previous offerings have tended to be flashier: gold-finished Trump sneakers for $399, an enticing Trump cologne for $99. The Bible, far from being a luxury object, inveighs against wealth. It tells of the life of a man who said things like “Blessed are the poor” and “Love your enemies”. Such sentiments are not easily mistaken for those of Mr Trump, which include “Part of the beauty of me is that I am very rich” and “The worst thing a man can do is go bald.”

;

;The market in religious publishing is thriving in America: the recent StatShot Annual Report from the Association of American Publishers found that revenues of religious presses had risen 7% in the first ten months of 2023, to $674m. A slice of that might defray at least some of Mr Trump's legal expenses, but this is a very unusual market, with obstacles for new entrants.

;

;The biggest is that many suppliers insist on giving its most popular product away for free. The Gideons, a Christian charity founded in 1899, has placed 2.5bn Bibles and New Testaments in hotels, hospitals, prisons and domestic-violence shelters around the world—roughly one for every Christian man, woman and child. Weary travellers yearning for gospel truths can simply reach into a bedside drawer and find some. Other groups have posted the entire Bible online, so the faithful can search for their favourite verses. Against such unfair, cut-price competition, can Mr Trump compete?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Probably, for several reasons. First, the revered text he is touting is not subject to copyright—a concept that did not exist when the King James Bible was first published in 1611. So he is demanding a high price for a text whose long-dead authors do not need paying 。 Never mind scribbling notes in the margins of the books of the minor prophets; the profit margins on each copy of this book should be major.

;

;None of that will matter if no one buys the God Bless the ;USA; Bible. But it has two celebrity endorsements: Lee Greenwood, the country star who sings “God Bless the ;USA;”, is involved, too. And Mr Trump is pushing the tome during a bitter election campaign, to a vast number of followers, many of whom are passionate both about scripture and about supporting the former president against his fiendish enemies.

;

;Others in the devotional publishing industry have faced the same challenge as Mr Trump—how to refresh a blockbuster written thousands of years ago—and come up with even more creative solutions. They cannot commission sequels by living authors, as the literary estates of Agatha Christie and Ian Fleming have done to produce new Hercule Poirot and James Bond stories. But they can commission new translations (a huge task) or tailor versions for specific audiences.

;

;Thus, from Zondervan, the Christian arm of HarperCollins, you can buy the “Boys Bible” (“Gross and gory stuff you never knew was in the Bible”). From a smaller German outfit, there is the “Biker Bible” (“the whole New Testament and life stories of bikers”). The Bible is long and confusing: many modern readers yearn for shortcuts to passages that might be especially relevant, and commentaries to aid comprehension. Others seek whimsy: you can buy the “Mother's Bible” (it's pink), or Bibles in regional dialects (a Glaswegian one opens with “In the Beginnin'”). There are even scriptures in fictitious tongues such as Klingon, from “Star Trek”, or Quenya, invented by JRR Tolkien.

;

;Such experimentation is much easier with the Bible than it is with the Koran, and much easier today than in previous centuries. In the 16th century the scholar William Tyndale translated the Bible from Hebrew and Greek into English. He was later burned at the stake for heresy. The church was less tolerant of novelty in those days, and created literal ghostwriters.

;

;Since many people take the Bible literally, careful proofreading is essential 。 In 1631 printers in London accidentally left the word “not” out of the seventh commandment, thus rendering it as “Thou shalt commit adultery.” This delighted many readers, but not the authorities. The printers were hit with ruinous fines and lost their licence. The “Wicked Bible” subsequently became a collector's item; surviving copies are now valued at tens of thousands of dollars. Whether future generations will treasure Mr Trump's Bible so dearly remains to be seen. ■

; ;;HE IDEA; of machines outsmarting humans has long been the subject of science fiction. Rapid improvements in artificial-intelligence (;AI;) programs over the past decade have led some experts to conclude that science fiction could soon become fact. On March 19th ;Jensen Huang;, the chief executive of Nvidia, the world's biggest manufacturer of computer chips and its third most valuable publicly traded company, said he believed today's models could advance to the point of so-called artificial general intelligence (;AGI;) within five years. What exactly is ;AGI;—and how can we judge when it has arrived?

;

;Mr Huang's words should be taken with a pinch of salt: Nvidia's profits have soared because of the ;growing demand for its high-tech chips;, which are used to train ;AI; models. Promoting ;AI; is thus good for business. But Mr Huang did set out a clear definition of what he believes would constitute ;AGI;: a program that can do 8% better than most people at certain tests, such as bar exams for lawyers or logic quizzes.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This proposal is the latest in a long line of definitions. In the 1950s Alan Turing, a British mathematician, said that talking to a model that had achieved ;AGI; would be indistinguishable from talking to a human. Arguably the most advanced ;large language models; already pass the Turing test.但近年来，科技领导者提出了一系列新的定义，从而改变了目标。 ;Mustafa Suleyman;, co-founder of DeepMind, an ;AI;-research firm, and chief executive of a newly established AI division within Microsoft, believes that what he calls “artificial capable intelligence”—a “modern Turing test”—will have been reached when a model is given $100,000 and turns it into $1m without instruction. (Mr Suleyman is a board member of ;The Economist;'s parent company.) Steve Wozniak, a co-founder of Apple, has a more prosaic vision of ;AGI;: a machine that can enter an average home and make a cup of coffee.

;

;Some researchers reject the concept of ;AGI; altogether 。伦敦国王学院的迈克·库克表示，这个词没有科学依据，而且对不同的人有不同的含义。 Few definitions of ;AGI; attract consensus, admits Harry Law, of the University of Cambridge, but most are based on the idea of a model that can outperform humans at most tasks—whether making coffee or making millions. In January researchers at DeepMind proposed six levels of ;AGI;, ranked by the proportion of skilled adults that a model can outperform: they say the technology has reached only the lowest level, with ;AI; tools equal to or slightly better than an ;unskilled human;.

;

;The question of what happens when we reach ;AGI; obsesses some研究人员。 Eliezer Yudkowsky, a computer scientist who has been fretting about AI for 20 years, worries that by the time people recognise that models have ;become sentient;, it will be too late to stop them and humans will become enslaved.但很少有研究人员同意他的观点。 Most believe that ;AI; is simply following human inputs, often poorly.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;There may be no consensus about what constitutes ;AGI; among academics or businessmen—but a definition could soon be agreed on in court. As part of a ;lawsuit; lodged in February against OpenAI, a company he co-founded, Elon Musk is asking a court in California to decide whether the firm's ;GPT-4; model shows signs of ;AGI;. ;;A;;NTI-ABORTION ACTIVISTS; were thrilled when Donald Trump won the presidency in 2016. Mr Trump had promised to appoint justices who would “automatically” overturn; Roe v Wade,; the 1973 case that protected reproductive rights. Three appointments later, the Supreme Court did just that in ;Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organisation.; But two years on, an oral argument on March 26th concerning mifepristone—a medication used in 63% of abortions in America—bodes ill for those hoping the court will help them keep limiting access to abortion care. At least for now.

;

;;Food and Drug Administration v Alliance for Hippocratic Medicine; concerns a challenge to mifepristone by a group of doctors who oppose abortion. They persuaded a lower-court judge to de-authorise the ;FDA;'s approval of the drug in 2000 despite a safety record comparable to Tylenol (paracetamol) and penicillin. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals somewhat softened that slap in the agency's face last August. But it blocked the ;FDA;'s moves in 2016 and 2021 allowing mifepristone to be used later in pregnancy (through ten weeks) and to be sent through the mail with a remote prescription.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Erin Hawley, representing the plaintiffs, defended the pill restrictions in her first argument at the Supreme Court. With her husband, Senator Josh Hawley, watching from the public gallery, she told the justices that the ;FDA;'s policy on mifepristone left her clients facing a “Hobson's choice”. Forcing doctors either to stand by their beliefs or care for a woman who took abortion pills and wound up in the emergency room, Ms Hawley said, is “intolerable”. Yet she faced deeply sceptical questioning from justices across the ideological spectrum as to whether her clients had suffered a concrete injury—a prerequisite for bringing a lawsuit in the first place.

;

;Colloquy about “standing”, or a lack thereof, consumed perhaps three-quarters of the 90-minute hearing. Justices Elena Kagan and Amy Coney Barrett teamed up to demonstrate that even Ms Hawley's two exemplars—Dr Christina Francis and Dr Ingrid Skop—had not suffered a concrete injury. Dr Francis may have had a patient who needed surgical attention after a complication from taking mifepristone, but she never raised an objection to treating her, Justice Kagan pointed out. And as Justice Barrett noted, it was actually her partner who performed the procedure, not Dr Francis herself: “I don't read either Skop or Francis” as having “ever participated” in ending the life of a fetus or embryo.

;

;The Alliance offered an alternative account of why the Alliance may have the right to sue—a theory known as “associational standing”. This is when an organisation brings a lawsuit based on harm to the organisation itself or to its members. Justice Clarence Thomas noted that it may be too “easy to manufacture” an injury rooted in an organisation's bare opposition to a policy if all it has to show is “diverted time and resources” associated with bringing the lawsuit. Meanwhile, Justice Samuel Alito suggested that the court has been flexible with standing in past cases and seemed exasperated by the possibility that no one could come up with a plausible plaintiff. “Is there anybody who can sue and get a judicial ruling on whether what ;FDA; did was lawful?”他问。 “Shouldn't ;somebody; be able to challenge that in court?” That's quite unlikely, replied Elizabeth Prelogar, the solicitor-general who ably defended the ;FDA;'s moves. But in any case, the plaintiffs in court don't “come within a hundred miles” of the Supreme Court's long-standing standards.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Several justices explored Ms Prelogar's claim that federal law provides “conscience protections” that “would guard against the injury the doctors face”. Justices Barrett and Brett Kavanaugh seemed satisfied with her assurance that the government would not force a doctor with an objection to ending fetal life to participate in an abortion. Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson added that the “obvious common-sense remedy” is to give individual doctors “an exemption” (which they already have) rather than, as she said to Ms Hawley, to “entertain your argument that no one else…in America should have this drug in order to protect your clients”.

;

;Justice Neil Gorsuch jumped on this suggestion. Single-judge district courts, he lamented, too often refashion themselves as “a nationwide legislative assembly” when blocking actions of the federal government. The judiciary's proper role, he said, is to “provide a remedy sufficient to address the plaintiff's asserted injuries and go no further”.

;

;Two justices seem ready to go significantly further. Justices Alito and Thomas invoked the Comstock Act, a law from 1873 that bans sending, among other “lewd” things, abortion medications and materials through the post. In 2022 the White House's Office of Legal Counsel said that this 150-year-old law only prohibits posting such materials to people who will use them unlawfully. But Justice Alito was incredulous that the ;FDA; did not at least mention the law when regulating mifepristone. And Justice Thomas told Jessica Ellsworth, the lawyer for Danco Laboratories (which markets the drug as Mifeprex) that it “specifically covers drugs such as yours”.

;

;If three more justices who were mum on this 19th-century law have a similar view, a future administration could succeed in banning the posting of abortion medication. But for now, it seems, the nearly 650,000 American women who end their pregnancies each year with abortion pills will not see their access curtailed.

;

;Visitors outside the Supreme Court on March 26th saw just how convenient mifepristone can be. Foot-high “Roe-bots” whizzed around the plaza ready to distribute abortion pills by prescription. Controlled by doctors in Massachusetts, New York and Washington, the bots can do a virtual consultation with a remote provider and dispense the medication on demand. A volunteer with Aid Access, the charity which organised the demonstration, noted the Roe-bots were perfectly legal. “It's all very by the book,” she said. ;■;
